The velocity of sound is significantly affected by the medium through which it is transmitted because sound waves travel at different speeds through different materials. In general, sound travels fastest through solids, slower through liquids, and slowest through gases. This variation in velocity is primarily due to the differences in the elastic and inertial properties of the mediums.

In solids, molecules are closely packed together, which enhances the efficiency of energy transfer between the particles when the sound wave propagates. This close packing results in a higher speed of sound due to the solid's higher elasticity compared to liquids and gases.

In liquids, the molecules are less tightly packed than in solids but are more densely packed than in gases, leading to a moderate speed of sound. The relatively lower elasticity compared to solids, yet higher than that of gases, accounts for the intermediate speed of sound in liquids.

Gases exhibit the slowest speed of sound among the three states of matter due to the significant distance between molecules. This larger distance causes a slower transfer of energy from one molecule to the next as a sound wave moves through the gas. Moreover, the speed of sound in gases is also greatly affected by temperature, increasing as the temperature rises.

Changing the medium alters the sound's velocity because each material possesses unique properties that either facilitate or hinder the transmission of sound waves. These properties, such as density and elasticity, directly influence how fast sound can travel through the medium.
